Yevgeny Prigozhin (Indicted by Mueller): Russian "Mafia" Involvement ?
This is interesting. He is estimated to being worth more than a billion rubles, but that isn't so very huge, in terms of comparison to the main Russian Oligarchs. He is quite a small fish to catch. One that may have been doing more than one type of business. The restaurant business, and particularly when it caters to the rich and powerful, is sometimes known as a potential listening post. A place where things can be overheard, and sometimes said, that would not be heard and said elsewhere. It is suspected that Prigozhin was in that type of business. You can sometimes make much more from scraps of information than you can make from selling hotdogs. So that might, or might not, tie him to organized crime, who also are known to engage in that type of traditional surveillance and tend to value, as well as find useful, that type of information acquisition...... 
What is evident is that there is no definite tie, of any sort, between him and the Russian government. That includes Putin, despite media sensationalism describing him as "Putin's chef". It seems a bit misleading and a bit desperate on the part of some of the American press. While the Russian mafia might well have utilized a small fish such as Prigozhin, that does not really take him far up the ladder. That in itself raises some interesting questions about who Prigozhin was working for, and why. Russian organized crime perhaps ? That would be an interesting finding. 
Oddly enough there have been prior allegations of Clinton ties to the Russian mafia. Then again there have been allegations of Trump ties to the Russian mafia as well. Both are equally suspect, on every level. Such ties might exist, and it might yet be proven that there are such ties, judicially. Which side, Democrats, or Republicans, will fall into it, at that point, is an open question. It all depends on what evidence happens to surface. 
Here is what Wikipedia provides on him. 
In 1990, after his release, he and his stepfather set up a network to sell hot dogs.[4] Soon, according to him, 'the rubles were piling up faster than his mother could count them.'[5] He also became the manager of and 15% stakeholder in "Contrast," started by Boris Spektr, a classmate from his boarding school, which was the first grocery store chain in Saint Petersburg. In 1995, when revenues began to fall, Prigozhin convinced a director at "Contrast," Kiril Ziminov, to open a restaurant with him. The two opened the "Old Customs House" (Russian: Старая Таможня), which was one of the first elite restaurants in Saint Petersburg. In 1997, inspired by waterfront restaurants on the Seine in Paris, Prigozhin and Ziminov spent $400,000 remodeling a rusting boat on the Vyatka River and started the floating restaurant "New Island," which quickly became one of the most fashionable dining spots in Saint Petersburg.[4][5] According to him, his patrons "wanted to see something new in their lives and were tired of just eating cutlets with vodka." In 2001, Prigozhin personally served food to Vladimir Putin and French president Jacques Chirac when they dined at "New Island", and to US President George W. Bush in 2002. In 2003, Putin celebrated his birthday at "New Island."[5] By 2003, Prigozhin had left his business partners and established his own independent restaurants. The Anti-Corruption Foundation accused Prigozhin of corrupt business practices; his illegal wealth estimated to be worth more than one billion rubles.[6]

By "early to mid-2016," Russians had decided to use whatever means at their disposal to help Donald Trump win.
The Russians bought political ads on social media sites and organized political rallies to achieve those goals.
Russians, disguising their identities, "communicated with unwitting individuals associated with the Trump campaign" in an attempt to "coordinate political activities."
None of that is a smoking gun of collusion.

"Unwitting" members of Trumpworld working with Russians, who didn't identify themselves as Russians, is not the same as a willful effort on behalf of members of the Trump campaign to actively collude with the Russian government.

But what this latest set of indictments proves beyond a shadow of a doubt is that, yes, Russia staged an aggressive and elaborate effort to influence the 2016 election.

Not Islamic Terrorism, nor nuclear North Korea, is the greatest threat facing America. No. For several years, our chief Intelligence officers (heads of the FBI and DIA) have said that the greatest danger now comes in the form of cyberattack. And in 2016, they were vindicated, as we suffered a cyber thrust into the very heart of our democracy, the election of President.

As the 2018 election approaches, Do we prepare for the next onslaught? Hardly. Trump has given no directive that direct action be taken to prevent or blunt another Russian cyberattack, nor is there in place any credible deterrence. In fact, Trump’s administration has chosen NOT to implement new sanctions that were ordered against a Russia as punishment for their 2016 interference. 

The NYTimes writes, “There should be no doubt that Russia perceives its past efforts as successful and views the 2018 U.S. midterm elections as a potential target for Russian influence operations,” said Mr. Coats, testifying alongside Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director; Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director; and other leading intelligence officials.

“Throughout the entire community, we have not seen any evidence of any significant change from last year,” Mr. Coats said.

The warnings were striking in their contrast to President Trump’s public comments. He has mocked the very notion of Russian meddling in the last election and lashed out at those who suggested otherwise.

Mr. Trump has not directed his intelligence officials to specifically combat Russian interference, they said. But Mr. Pompeo said that the president has made clear that the C.I.A. has “an obligation, from the foreign intelligence perspective, to do everything we can to make sure there’s a deep and thorough understanding of every threat, including threats from Russia.”

Russia appears eager to spread information — real and fake — that deepens political divisions. Bot armies promoted partisan causes on social media, including the recent push to release a Republican congressional memo critical of law enforcement officials.

The bots have also sought to portray the F.B.I. and Justice Department as infected by partisan bias, said Senator Mark Warner of Virginia, the top Democrat on the intelligence committee.

“Other threats to our institutions come from right here at home,” he said. “There have been some, aided and abetted by Russian internet bots and trolls, who have attacked the basic integrity of the F.B.I. and the Justice Department. This is a dangerous trend.”

Trump flees reporters after indictment proves he’s wrong about Russia! Among other things, the charges allege that Russians working for the Kremlin-backed Internet Research Agency created false American personas and stole the identities of real Americans as part of an effort that was aimed at “supporting the presidential campaign of then-candidate Donald Trump (“Trump Campaign”) and disparaging Hillary Clinton.”

Importantly, the indictment puts to rest Trump’s claims that the Russian investigation is a “hoax” or a “witch-hunt” — claims that he has made repeatedly, including in specific reference to the idea that Russians used social media to manipulate American voters.

Naturally, with the explosive new indictment in hand, reporters wanted to know if Trump still believes the claims that he has clung to for well over a year.

He was confronted by some of those reporters Friday afternoon as he left the White House to board Marine One.

“Do you still the Russia investigation is a hoax?” one reporter asked. Others wanted to know about his failure to impose sanctions on Russia, asking, “Will you punish Russia?” and “Will you put sanctions on Russia?”

Trump had no answers for the press — but he did awkwardly give them a thumbs-up as they probed him about a foreign adversary’s efforts to undermine our democracy. #MuellerTime

Trump brushed it off as a hoax. He mused that it might be China, or a guy from New Jersey, or “somebody sitting on their bed who weighs 400 pounds.” He said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had assured him it wasn’t true. And, he added, “I really believe that when he tells me that, he means it.”President Trump has never stopped belittling the charge that Russia meddled in the 2016 presidential election. But on Friday, with the indictment of 13 Russians for orchestrating a vast, well-funded operation to interfere in the election, those denials collided with a mountain of evidence arrayed by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.
For Mr. Trump, who has tried to discredit Mr. Mueller’s investigation as a politically motivated witch hunt, it was a direct assault on the version of reality that he has sought tirelessly to create. In a tweet, Mr. Trump played up Mr. Mueller’s assertion that the Russian operation had begun in 2014, well before he declared his candidacy. “The Trump campaign did nothing wrong — no collusion!” he wrote.
Far from being rattled, Mr. Trump was elated, according to his advisers, because he viewed it as evidence that Mr. Mueller now knows who the malefactors are — and they do not include him or members of his team. (The indictment refers to campaign officials who met or communicated with Russians, but says they were “unwitting.”)
Yet Mr. Trump sidestepped the fact that he has stubbornly denied Russia’s interference, even after two assessments by the nation’s intelligence agencies concluded that Russia had meddled. Last November, during a trip to Asia, Mr. Trump said that Mr. Putin had told him that Russia did not meddle, and that he was inclined to believe him.
“Every time he sees me he says, ‘I didn’t do that,’ and I really believe that when he tells me that, he means it,” Mr. Trump said. “I think he is very insulted by it,” he added, “which is not a good thing for our country.”
Mr. Trump went so far as to suggest that the heads of the intelligence agencies at the time of the 2016 election — John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director; James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence; and James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director — were less trustworthy than Mr. Putin. American English Lesson #5 - The Art of Story Telling

One of the most important cultural aspects of the Americans communication comprehension is telling stories to provide a mental picture of what we are talking about. This follows the use of parables in the Bible. The Messiah relied on relating to people with everyday ordinary life experience that people could relate to. Here's an example:

The Story of a Man Named Ken

Once upon a time there was a man named Ken. People loved and respected Ken so much they began naming suff after him. As Americans explored and settled the wild west they began establishing new states. A particularly hilly region organized and requested Statehood to join America. Contemplating what to name this new United State, they decided it needed to be named after the man named Ken. So being hilly and all this provided many little hidden valley's known as tucky's. Thus the State of Ken's Tucky or Kentucky became a US State. Now Kentucky was well known throughout the world for a special art form of story telling and talking in a manner not heard anywhere else in the world. For example when they were sharing good news with each other people would exclaim "Dawn. That is worth Killen for". This word was also founded on naming things after Ken. They just put "ill" in the middle of Ken. Example" One lucky fella got lucky and proudly proclaimed he had got a date with the most attractive women in town. She was a Playboy Model. Folks proclaimed "Now that is worth killen for " with great emphasis and joy for the fella. 

So the word Ken become used as the starting point to create new names of things people wanted to talk about. Do a word search and see how many times folks made words using the man named Ken. 

Now to the point of the Story. President Donald Trump's highest and truly remarkable achievement? In ONLY his first year in office is (drum roll please): He has told MORE STORIES than ALL OTHER PRESIDENTS COMBINED. IN JUST ONE YEAR. A feat that will never be equaled.

Trump Versus the Russians:

As the article notes, it is very probable that there is no "clear case" against Trump, or his campaign team, proving any "collusion" or conspiracy, between the accused Russians, named in the indictment, and the Trump camp. I agree, thus far, with that. A very different situation would result if someone where to surface evidence that proves, within judicial standards of evidence, beyond a reasonable shadow of a doubt, that persons in the Trump team in any way directed, informed, or utilized the Russians in support of the Trump election bid. That is, I tend to think, extremely unlikely, but there is no definite proof that that did not occur either. So there will be a lot of public speculation. Democrats and disgruntled Republicans, as well as the disaffected and disaffiliated, within America will be speculating on the basis of their current political stance and affinity. Some will have very strong viewpoints, and will feel certain that they know who is guilty and who is not, as well as of what they are guilty. That presents a big, somewhat unusual, problem. It is the type of problem that demands that the stops be pulled out and that everything possible be done to dig up "the whole truth and nothing but the truth" on the key questions, as to who, what, when, where and why. 

It is the "why" part of the puzzle that is the most difficult, and yet the Mueller team seems intent on convincing America, and being convinced themselves, that the Russians did it to support Trump. They add Sanders into that category as well. There might be some judicial evidence that we do not know anything about as of yet, proving that particular, very crucial, point. However, the full text of the indictment, although appearing very opinionated on motives, in that regard, has no real judicial evidence to offer that proves that opinion to be justified. The link between the accused Russians and the Trump team is still quite lacking. There is no evidence of collusion. 

I contend that there is no solid evidence of the Russians motive. That the allegations, rather read that as "opinions", as to Russian motives are still quite baseless as to actual evidentiary facts, and their proper interpretation. Sloppy workmanship, it might seem, for such a veteran FBI man who should likely know better. Unless Mueller is going to suddenly pull a rabbit out of his hat, the idea that the Russians were fully and solely intent on supporting Donald Trump's election to the Presidency, seems fatally flawed, and likely will be seen as such judicially. Certainly there is plenty of room to poke lots of holes in that theory. Unless again, Mueller pulls a rabbit out of his hat, that he has not given any indications of being able to produce. 

Thus far the one side inquiry seems intent to tie any evidence of foreign wrong doing to the Trump campaign and to Donald Trump, directly or indirectly. I do not see that point as being proven to any sufficient extent. It still ranks in the realm of slander and libel, not judicial fact, though that could change, if the solid evidence comes forward that we currently do not really see any of. After all the Russians could have been slamming Hillary Clinton for the purpose of making it look like the Trump team is involved and/or doing that. That, as I have discussed previously, and in detail, would NOT help Trump's election. It is very arguable, based on what experts know about such things, that that type of action would harm rather than help Trump. So there is a big problem and right now, until that rabbit is materialized, Mueller looks far too partisan and biased. He might not have meant it to come out that way, but to many he will look that way, until evidence of "collusion" is produced, by whatever means necessary to produce it. 

On the other hand it is time to call for as much attention to the Democrats, of the Clinton campaign, as being suspects of election "collusion" with the Russians. It could go that way if the digging commences and the political corpses are exhumed and examined in sufficient detail. There is nothing certain about the "who done it" on the American side of the international fence, but perhaps Vladimir Putin can help, before this mess escalates into a new Cold War, or something similarly unfortunate, as to American hatred and prejudice being fed, against Russia. That is the larger problem now. Larger than the relatively large problem of corruption within the democratic process and system that has raised the spectre of its ugly head above the horizon of so many uncertainties. 

There are many reasons why Russians would have chosen to help the Clinton campaign and would have sought to do damage to the Trump campaign. The weight is on that side, and far more reason to think that the Russians feared a Republican victory. 

On the other hand Mueller has made the FBI look quite bad. The simple fact that it was their job to detect, and stop, the types of actions and activities that he notes in the indictment. Why where at least some of those Russians not caught, red handed, arrested, and tried, long before now ?  They were getting away with it, and if not for the very special nature of the Mueller inquiry, and its exceptional powers, the Russians would likely have gotten away with it all. There is a very real point of concern as to the current effectiveness of FBI activities against foreign espionage, and other illegal activities. They seem ineffective at best. Odd that Mueller has, likely inadvertently, raised that very significant point. Expect some heated debate on that one too. After all if the Russians could carry out what they did in regard to election meddling imagine what foreign nations can do in the area of espionage. Seems that they have a wide open field, the USA, to operate in. Something we have suspected for a while, as Cold War wariness died down and turned its blind eye.
